JuWFjEwRIS0vqrTsuD5Hog.text: My friend and I came to The Pelican for their Sunday Champagne Brunch. They offer three different pricing ranges (children, basic with no alcohol and a price inclusive of alcohol). We opted for the S$98++ which was only inclusive of free flow sodas and juices. Juices offered were: apple, grapefruit, pineapple, orange and cranberry. Their concept of buffet is not the walk around and fill your plate up and return to the table to eat. We had four full hours to sit and enjoy our made to order dishes. The staff started us off with the oyster and prawn platter (which is one order per person). We each get 2 fresh oysters and 4 shrimp. Later the grilled platter arrived (also one order allowed). The grilled platter came with 4 grilled oysters, 2 halves of a lobster, a grilled barramundi, and a grilled cuttlefish. Just receiving those two plates, the serving was decent. Later we also ordered the small plates (which you can order multiple times). We tried the beef sliders, lobster slider, corn, brocollini, truffle fries, clam chowder, NY striploin, and crab cake. The small platters are truly small platters. One slider, one crab cake and a small serving of steak nicely sliced in bite sizes. This is great so that we do not waste food, and each dish is prepared as you order, so they were all hot and juicy, which was greatly appreciated. There was a longer list of other options available to order, such as another soup, snapper pie (which looked amazing), seafood linguini and more. But we were so full with the above that we had to save the little room left for dessert. For dessert, they had three options: Ice cream, red velvet cake and a banana bread. The banana bread was delicious! The whole 3 hours we were there there were only another four of five groups there. Which was perfect, as it was not crowded or noisy. We could sit comfortably and chat and service was prompt to take our orders. And free-flow drinks is true - we had cranberry, pineapple, apple and a coke . I would say that for the quality and type of food and quantity we ate, we were able to get a good bang for our buck. Yes, it is overall on the pricier end, but, the ambience, location, and quality of the food was on par with the price. I would go back again with a bigger group, so then we can share and try more dishes. Just make sure your group has a good appetite!

QRagSKZpWnyisFC6bgKW_A.text: Pretty epic front-row center view of Marina Bay Sands and the Singapore River if you sit on the outdoor patio. Great for a chill weekday 1-for-1 happy hour deal with some friends or co-workers. The wine / beer selection for the happy hour is nothing extraordinary, but it does the trick. Service for refills could've been better.The happy hour menu has most of the usual suspects for fried bar food: fried calamari, fried chicken wings, fries, etc.

lMZdWQP8WN6nwanawyq-rg.text: We had a sumptuous meal and a lovely, leasurely lunch. The wait staff was gracious and we thoroughly enjoyed our experience.

IyfgKH2LiGORwer7O6b6dA.text: My steak was nice, the service wasn't as good as I remembered from last time. I had the rib eye, cooked well not too over facing.I would recommend trying this place

photos.caption: Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore. Nice fitout

LosE0zjNZiapdJt4c8WrTg.text: Why is stuff so overpriced here?I knew I should've stuck to my guns and used the Entertainer app for a 1:1 deal. But noooooo, I had to listen to my stupid stomach and order the seafood platter instead. It certainly looked good, but you soon discover that the mussels were microscopic, and so were the clams, and the prawns weren't quite as large or fresh as you'd expect. Think: cooked prawns you buy from Woolworths. Lobster and crab were good, as were the oysters. (NB: $8 each for oysters?? It's almost cheaper to buy a plane ticket to NYC to eat the oysters there!)We decided that the platter wasn't enough for us, and being Asian, needed carbs. So we ordered the 'signature' linguine with clams. It came out well presented with plenty of clams. But totally lacked any flavour. Couldn't taste the wine, couldn't taste the clams, could certainly taste the overly generous garlic. Could've also done with an extra pinch or two of salt. Service was great (mostly) and friendly, and it's a very pretty place to eat and impress a girl on a date. $200 for 2 (no drinks) is a little steep for what came out though.

photos.caption: Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore. Seafood platter $138++ (not worth it)

g53rTcJG-A6WDlOnxCnWKA.text: The service was lacklustre and the waitress who was serving us was clearly not very well trained. She didn't know what was on the daily catch. Also had to keep asking for the prices. We had to ask for our bill twice as well. Trying to spilt the check was too much an hassle that we didn't bother with it.Food-wise the pie ran out and we were told until we attempted to order it. The burger my friend order was medium-rare despite her asking for medium. The king crab lobster pasta was over garlicky and thus any flavour from the seafood was fairly masked.Gave an extra star cos the location let us caught a little fireworks.For the price I paid? I was severely disappointed and will never step in ever again. Such abysmal service is a huge deterrence.

IS4rduSYjDPINffE-5Z7xw.text: Pretty chill place to get drinks or to take your tourist visitors to for the marina view in the evening, can even catch the laser show from there. The happy hour is decent but the mojito I had hardly had much alcohol in it. I haven't tried the food here so can't recommend it.

8HYXL45tpzAGy82xLSCiPQ.text: Went here last night with some friends after watching the extreme boat races. There were seven of us and they had no problem seating us without a reservation. We sat on the patio and enjoyed the light show at Marina Bay Sans. The service was pretty good, but it seems they had some issues keeping orders straight and I waited about 20 minutes to get my still water after everyone in the group had already received their cocktails. We ordered the ribeye steak with mashed potatoes and the burger with fries without the bun to split. My husband threw in an order for a side of fries after everything arrived because the portions weren't enough to feed two people who had completed the #FilthyFifty #Crossfit workout earlier that day. The steak was cooked perfectly and came on a small spread of mashed potatoes (approx 4 bites). I was happy with the burger, but found myself wanting veggies or something to round the meal out. The fries and the mashed just didn't do it for me. Overall, decent place with good drinks and food. Patio is nice. Service needs a little bit of work and the portions could be a bit larger with more variety. Happy we tried it, but there was nothing outstanding that will bring us back in unless we're in the area and looking for a place to get in quickly.

photos.caption: Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore. Ribeye steak with mash ($58)
Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore. Burger without bun for Paleo folk ($35)
Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore. Menu

YBP5nlo7GcOYitZpdtnw_A.text: Dining at the Pelican brings me back to those movies in which the lead characters would dine at a waterfront seafood restaurant, enjoying a plate of fish and chips with some beer while watching the seagulls fly. There is no fish and chips here or any picturesque sea view, but there is a gorgeous view of Marina Bay and bountiful marine favourites to feast at Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill. Helmed by Austrian Chef Jonathan Sparber, the Pelican introduces an all-new "RAW" bar featuring delicacies such as Maine Lobsters and caviar. The concept of raw food was rather fuzzy to me initially. I thought I was going to have only raw food for the entire dinner. But as often said, the best way to digest an unfamiliar concept is to taste them.                                     A fraction of the menu is now devoted to the "raw" bar where diners can choose from lobsters, scallops, tuna to be done steamed, broiled and served cold, or torched. Hence, the seafood is not truly as raw as the usual Japanese sashimi, but more precisely prepared in a minimalistic way to showcase the sweetness of the meat. The scampi ($18 for 3pcs) which resembled a baby lobster, turned out ridiculously sweet when dipped in the fragrant seafood-infused butter sauce.The scallops ($18) were tender and juicy but the spotlight fell easily to the Trout Roe Brioche ($18). Half of the trout roe has been marinated with beetroot juices, thus explaining its dark red hues. Piled on top of buttered brioche, the roe brought a riot of "popping" effect on the tastebuds but they were a little too salty to go with the chewy bread. I am usually quite lazy when it comes to de-shelling crabs but I gladly make an exception for these brown crabs ($69) which were delicate and meaty. The selection of oysters here are impressive as well. Though we didn't get the XXL oysters that were harvested from Bouziges France, the Fanny Bay oysters from Canada ($8/pc)  were already as big as the palm of an average male adult. But size doesn't count when it comes to oysters as it seems like the majority of us preferred the smaller speciales oceanes from France ($9/pc) as they were milky, sweet but not too overwhelming. There's something of the entente cordiale to the main food menu as well. Starters range from soothing bowl Cream of Corn Soup with mussels and polenta ($18) to an artistic plate of Poached Lobster ($28). Fresh, sweet chunks of lobster meat are arranged on fennel, guarded by 2 kinds of polka dots made of avocado purée and Mary Rose cocktail-based mayonnaise. Old fashioned crab cakes ($24) is a kind of dish that is in vogue but none of those I've tried so far has ever come as good as these from the Pelican. They are so generous with the crab meat that I was startled when I took a bite of it. Perfectly seasoned and not greasy at all. Seafood are clearly the focus here, as all main courses except the steak and the burger are either fish or clams. This is not an issue as I am partial towards seafood. The Daily Catch of the Day was Halibut served on beetroot purée. While it is perfectly alright to skip the aesthetic aspect for home-cooked dishes, the presentation of this fish should not be less emphasized, especially when diners are forking out more than an average of $40 for a dish. Unfortunately, the bland taste did not make up for this dish as well. All is not lost as the Glacier 51 Toothfish ($45) was an impeccable dish. It was not only more visually attractive to the eye, but also appealing on its flavors and textures. The unique brioche crust gave the meat a crisp surface while the olives and corn sauce did not drown out the nuances of the meat. Rounding of the seafood feast are some refreshing yet unique home-made liquorice ice creams created by the experimental chef. The flavors changed randomly so you might even get beetroot on your visit. The tangy sour cream & white wine ice cream contrasted beautifully with the caramelized sweetness of the Banana Bread Pudding ($16), which managed to be not too rich. I would pick this over the Whoopie Pie ($16), which wasn't truly as heavy or overly sweet as it looked, but the sponge layers could be moister. Overall, I think seafood is still the forte of the Pelican and if you love fresh seafood, the Pelican will not go wrong. Nonetheless, a full dinner here does not come cheap so it is more suitable as the place for special occasions when you feel like pampering yourselves or your loved ones.

oPVn3y-EMh1QPpaodS1jqg.text: I popped in here on Saturday afternoon because I had a hankering for oysters.  It was an added bonus that they had two for one drinks.  Now, I know that alcohol is expensive here, but house chardonnay for $15 a glass still makes me cringe, but with the two for one deal at least I felt like it was $7, although the pour was def. not full.  I ordered a half dozen oysters, which were okay, nothing super awesome, some old bay fries (not nearly enough seasoning) and the crab cakes which took over 30 minutes to come out, but were easily the star of my meal.  Service was all over the place, fairly slow, and I had different people coming by my table at all times.  The view was really nice, but the prices were a little insane.  Lunch for what I had was $S121.  A bit steep for some oysters and house wine.  All in all, I'd pop back in for 2-1 drinks and those crab cakes.

iN2XBq-EqnkeK__Oc8ccHw.text: The Pelican is a great spot for afterwork drinks as it boasts the triple threat of great drink specials in a beautiful setting with excellent service.From 5p-8p, drinks are 1 for 1 (i.e., buy 1 get 1 free), which makes it one of the only places where I've ever gotten a beer for $5 bucks in Singapore!  Even better, the servers are nice enough to hold your free drink at the bar, so you always have a cold libation.If you feel a bit peckish, there are also nice bar bites including peppered candied bacon, old bay fries and house cured pickles.PARTING THOUGHT: Be sure to request a table by the water to get an up close and personal view of the MBS light show!

photos.caption: Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore. 1 for 1 happy hour = 2 beers for $10++

Dg2fADQXmO2Jcm5XgTYRuQ.text: Really nice ambiance (beautiful views of the bay if you're sitting on the patio) but the food here is really overpriced for the quality. My party of 6 ordered 2 crab cakes, 2 pelican potted prawns,  1 pelican platter, 1 double atlantic linguini and clams, and 1 halibut special (this is not on their usual menu) for the table to share. The potted prawns were really disappointing (kind of like a prawn mayo salad) and the linguini was pretty tasteless. The crab cakes were the best dish (the only dish I would recommend). All the seafood on the pelican platter was fresh but nothing spectacular although the portions were big.In terms of service, the staff were super friendly and helpful, although we had to wait 15mins to be seated even though we had a reservation (the staff apologized for this).Overall nice place for the views and service but definitely no wow factor for food.

photos.caption: Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore. Pelican platter

7A722vswNcs3Z3U3Sp_3zA.text: Staff was great. Beautiful view of the bay and Marina Sands. Need to reserve the best seats to watch the sunset.

photos.caption: Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore

tOnSIx7UIsTmtw5xkvC01w.text: The Pelican is excellent. We ordered the seafood platter, Irish oysters, lobster rice, linguini and clams. All the seafood was really fresh, the lobster especially was cooked to perfection - on the seafood platter (steamed) and as part of the lobster rice (grilled). The service is great, very attentive - as they should be considering the prices! Though that being said, i think it's worth the money. Desserts were good, definitely try the pineapple ice cream and lime biscuit. The red velvet cake and whoopie pie is massive, so only order that if you're sharing.

photos.caption: Photo of The Pelican Seafood Bar & Grill - Singapore, Singapore. Pineapple ice cream and lime biscuit

s6yMR9Eb1Z-OlNHZfHdJNg.text: I think The Pelican is fairly new, having taken over the premises Pierside Kitchen & Bar, though I can't say for sure 'how new'.First things first, I love the decor. Red leather booths, quirky light fixtures, a bar that dominates an entire wall... it's definitely dressed to impress. The first time I walked past I had already made up my mind to try it, and so try it I did!I was quite conflicted on whether to give The Pelican 3 or 4 stars. I'd like to give this 3.5 stars, but alas. So caveat:IGNORE MY 3 STAR RATING, if you order the right dishes, it's a 4 STAR EXPERIENCE. Most of the dishes and items I've tried there have been mainly three star, maybe barely four star dishes, but I have to talk about the one five star dish I've tried from their menu. The Baked Snapper Pie. Ladies and gentlemen, this is as a good a fish pie as you'll find in Singapore. It's a huge swath of puff pastry that's golden brown and is so buttery you can smell butter before even breaking into the crush. It comes to the table piping how, dashing, and delicious.Breaking it open you'll find firm morsels of white fish (apparently they don't ALWAYS use snapper), cooked in a cream sauce with asparagus, mushrooms, and I think a bit of onion or fennel. The fish "stew" is amazing. The fish is fresh, firm, and the cream really carries the flavours of the asparagus and onions (I think there were onions) very well. It's so flavourful but so hot (temperature wise) that you end up in that conundrum of I WANT MORE IN MY MOUTH and OWW OW OW HOT HOT HOT. Trust me. Good food hurts.Other dishes I've tried include their Crab Louis, a light crabmeat salad with asparagus that was light, refreshing and tasty... though a little small in terms of portion size. The Pelican chowder is technically more a bisque, not being either cream or tomato based, it uses shellfish stock for the rusty brown colour. It's boldly flavoured and quite tasty though. The Black Peppered Candied Bacon caught my eye, and although it basically tastes like peppery bak kwah, it's an interested dish that has a great idea, but is poorly executed. (Bacon needs to be crisssspy)My most recent visit had me trying the Pelican platter, which is a lobster, a crab, 4 oysters, about 5-6 clams, 4 or 5 prawns, a little pot of swordfish ceviche and a marinated conch salad. The lobster was very fresh, and very easy to eat. The claws had been pulled and cracked, the head had been mixed with the coral, capers and parsley into a delicious lobster salad, the tail pre-cut so all you had to do was lever the meat out of the shell. The crab was bursting with roe, and very robustly flavoured... and the conch salad was marinated very well, and quite appetitizing. I don't take oysters but I'm told they were pretty good in terms of quality. Everything else on that plate? Meh. I'm just not a HUGE seafood person though, so maybe for real seafood fanatics, it might have been more enjoyable. Overall it seems clear that The Pelican is making a clear attempt on Luke's position as THE place for Boston-style seafood. While the snapper pie here is definitely a little better, and only one third the price of, Luke's lobster pie (which says A LOT), the advantage in price on everything else is also offset by slightly less panache in the way dishes are executed. It definitely gives Luke's a run for their money... but The Pelican (in my opinion), still doesn't quite match up.
